head.title: To Freeze the Dance of Shadow and Light

hedline.hl1: To Freeze the Dance of Shadow and Light

abstract.p: Serge J-F Levy letter disputes July 21 editorial on photography; says any part of process of capturing decisive moment is not function of luck; drawings (S)

block.p: As a working photojournalist who strives to maximize the aesthetic and journalistic qualities of my photographs, I was somewhat surprised by the comparison between the work of the amateur and greats like Henri Cartier-Bresson, Eugene Atget and Walker Evans (editorial, July 21).
In particular, I do not believe that any part of the process of capturing the decisive moment is a function of ''luck.''

As a working photojournalist who strives to maximize the aesthetic and journalistic qualities of my photographs, I was somewhat surprised by the comparison between the work of the amateur and greats like Henri Cartier-Bresson, Eugene Atget and Walker Evans (editorial, July 21).
In particular, I do not believe that any part of the process of capturing the decisive moment is a function of ''luck.''

Having looked at thousands of photographs taken by friends and relatives who suggest that they captured a striking moment, I have become convinced that great photographs are not ''accidental.'' Rather, a careful skill of connecting one's intent with an ability to compose and time a moment leads to a masterpiece.

I would suggest that the anonymous amateur photographs described in your editorial are not happenstance occurrences or ''the luck of the living moment,'' but rather an amateur's diligent work at cultivating a particular skill that some call the job of being a photographer.
SERGE J-F. LEVY New York, July 21, 2000
